title: [DevOps Adoption] Lazy loading / refreshing group data
description:
### Problem to solve

After [refactoring Segments into "enabled" groups](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297583), only groups that were already in a Segment will be "enabled" and there will be no way to enable data collection for any more groups.

### Proposal

In the instance-level "add groups" modal, selecting any group that is not already "enabled" should automatically enable it. This enabling should occur when the modal selections are saved and the modal is closed.

When user picks a group in modal, send API request to enable the feature if it's not enabled yet. Then start querying for data until there is some.

See the [original proposal](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297667#note_491061505).

epic.title: Modify DevOps Adoption to focus on groups rather than segments

title: Allow DAST to send certificates for mutual TLS
description:
### Problem to solve 

Allow DAST to be configured to send certificates with requests for mutual TLS.

Due to technical issues, the scope of this issue has been adjusted so the feature only works for legacy/ZAP-based scans. The feature will not work on browser-based scans. This work will be captured in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325224.

### Intended users

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)

* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)

### Proposal

Allow DAST to be configured to send certificates with requests for mutual TLS.

### Further details

Customer reports `HTTP:Error 400` with DAST in an environment that requires Mutual TLS.


### Available Tier

* Ultimate/Gold

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

DAST is able to be configured to send certificates with requests for mutual TLS.

### Links / references

Customer ticket: https://gitlab-federal-support.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/513 (internal use)

From the customer:

```
The problem we have is that we use mutual TLS in all of our systems, this also includes all of our user base as well, so when testing with DAST we need to have it send certs with every call made to port 443.
```
<!-- Label reminders - you should have one of each of the following labels.
Use the following resources to find the appropriate labels:
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/labels
- https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product/categories/features/
-->

### Implementation plan

We'll instruct users to create a protected, [File]() type CI variable named `DAST_PKCS12_CERTIFICATE` in the UI. If provided, DAST will use it when making requests by itself, through ZAP, and through Browserker.

Links:
- https://www.zaproxy.org/docs/desktop/ui/dialogs/options/certificate/ (implement in ZAP)
- https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/refs/heads/lkgr/docs/linux/cert_management.md


- [ ] Read `DAST_PKCS12_CERTIFICATE` into DAST
- [ ] Use the certificate when authenticating with the target
- [ ] Use the certificate for requests made by ZAP
- [ ] Use the certificate for requests made by Browserker
- [ ] Update docs with information on using a client-side certificate

### Release notes 

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

### Problem to solve 

<!-- What is the user problem you are trying to solve with this issue? -->

We need to evaluate semgrep against our existing analyzers. The best way we know to enable this need is to create a semgrep-based analyzer that we can use to compare against one we already have. Based upon usage, an analyzer which scans against python has been identified as our highest priority.

This new analyzer needs to conform to existing SAST features at their identified licensing levels.

### Questions to Answer

- [x] Should we have semgrep in a single analyzer project or many analyzer projects for each language/framework?
  - [x] Can semgrep scan multiple languages/frameworks in a single run? This was answered today in a call with r2c, semgrep will scan as many languages for which you have rules defined. As that is true, we should start with a single analyzer project that will work on many projects.

### Proposal 

<!-- Use this section to explain the feature and how it will work. It can be helpful to add technical details, design proposals, and links to related epics or issues. -->

- [x] Create https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/semgrep
- [x] Wrap [semgrep](https://semgrep.dev) with our [analyzer pattern](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/common)
- [x] Bake semgrep rules into Docker image so that the rules are versioned.
- [x] Limit semgrep rules to only python rules so that we don't create duplicates found in other analyzers.
- [x] Ensure feature parity with other analyzers:
  - [x] Enabled by existing SAST vendored template behind the [SAST_EXPERIMENTAL_FEATURES](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/sast/#experimental-features) env var.
  - [x] Run at same licensure as other SAST analyzers.
  - [x] Match existing support for custom rulesets.
  - [x] Field mappings - severity, location, field descriptions
  - [x] ultimate licensing limit for requisite features
    - [x] custom rulesets (dir/path exlusions)
  - [x] SEARCH_MAX_DEPTH
  - [x] Logging
  - [x] Must work offline
- [x] Investigate SARIF output as a way to generate a report. This could have a great impact on report generation down the line if it isn't too difficult.
- [x] Create downstream qa tests
- [x] Document new semgrep analyzer

### Notes

This may be a good starting point:

```
$ git clone https://github.com/we45/Vulnerable-Flask-App
$ semgrep --config p/bandit Vulnerable-Flask-App
```

title: bundler-audit scans fail because of --quiet CLI flag (broken master)
description:
### Summary

The [bundler-audit analyzer](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/ruby-bundler/-/jobs/980683674#L42) breaks on new scans (in development).

It doesn't affect the latest version of the analyzer (`bundler-audit:2`) but will prevent the publishing of new versions as the build will fail.

### Steps to reproduce

1. go to bundler audit analyzer project https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit
2. run pipeline for master https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit/-/pipelines/new
3. observe that downstream ruby projects fail (e.g. https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit/-/pipelines/245565353)

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/ruby-bundler/-/jobs/980683674#L42

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Scanning of ruby projects fails with:

```
exit status 1
```

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Scanning should succeed.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/ruby-bundler/-/jobs/980683674#L42

### Possible fixes

After some triaging, it seems that the underlying `bundler-audit scanner` doesn't pin its logger (`thor`) version: https://github.com/rubysec/bundler-audit/blob/master/gemspec.yml#L13

This means that even though both `bundler` and `bundler-audit` scanner are pinned in the analyzer's Dockerfile (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit/-/blob/master/Dockerfile#L35), the underlying logging library will still be updated. This causes the scanning error because the `thor` gem went from `1.0.1` to `1.1.0` two days ago.

The effect of this is as follows:
- `bundler-audit scanner` sets logging options to quiet (hoping to ensure that the scan only has an exit code without anything written to stdout)
- in `bundler-audit scanner` with `thor 1.0.1` this `quiet` option was ignored so that even if you set quiet you still got a full output (see [bundler-audit-gem-output.text](/uploads/fb3bde0a10239c14e42c1a0e75e1487d/bundler-audit-scanner.text))
- `bundler-audit` analyzer uses the scanner's output to decide whether vulnerabilities were found by checking for the line "Vulnerabilities found!" (and uses the output to generate the scanning report), but it sets the `--quiet` option on the `bundle audit check` command  https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/bundler-audit/-/blob/master/analyze.go#L68
- because the `--quiet` option was ignored in `thor 1.0.1` the analyzer continued to work until `thor 1.1.0` where this bug was fixed (https://github.com/erikhuda/thor/blob/df6663e9070fe254a308642db4f3efdc474d6ca9/lib/thor/shell/basic.rb#L97)
- because the analyzer relies on the old (incorrect) logging implementation, scanning breaks with the new fix

The `bundler-audit` `stable` and `major` images are not affected by this because the new version of `thor` was released 2 days ago (2021-01-20) https://github.com/erikhuda/thor/releases and no new analyzer releases have happened since then. However, running the pipeline on the analyzer's master branch breaks because the new `thor` version is used on docker build. This will be confusing for those making changes to the analyzer.

The fix is to:
1. remove the `--quiet` flag on the `bundle audit check` command
1. to check for the presence of vulnerabilities, just check the last line of the output

title: Improve testability of StandardContext
description:
We currently test sending events with `StandardContext` like so:
```ruby
expect_snowplow_event(category: 'epics', action: 'promote', property: 'issue_id', value: issue.id,
                                  standard_context: kind_of(Gitlab::Tracking::StandardContext))
```

Perhaps we can build the `standard_context` part of the expectation into the `expect_snowplow_event` helper. We should also encourage the user to specify what arguments are being passed to `StandardContext`.

Example:
```ruby
expect_snowplow_event(category: 'epics', action: 'promote', property: 'issue_id', value: issue.id,
                                  namespace: namespace, project: project)
```

title: Remove .add-border + borderless prop from CI Icon when used together
description:
### Description

Some of the CI Icons in the Merge Request page (mr_widget_pipeline.vue) have the following:

```vue
<ci-icon :status="status" :size="24" :borderless="true" class="add-border" />
```

Having both `borderless` and `add-border` are pretty contradictory...

### Solution

Remove both borderless and add border to have them simply as:

```vue
<ci-icon :status="status" :size="24" />
```

### UI impact

Even though one would expect these two conditions to "cancel out", side by side the look slightly different:

![image](/uploads/5d78b209a9c875ed9bcbb3abfb46abb8/image.png)

- At the top: `<ci-icon :status="status" :size="24" />`
  - After checking with @v_mishra for ~UX input, we agreed to have this version take precedence.
- At the bottom: `<ci-icon :status="status" :size="24" :borderless="true" class="add-border" />`

As we want to achieve more consistency, we may want to choose only one style overall.

### Technical Information

- Possible cleanup if either `.add-border` or the `borderless` prop are not used anymore, they should be removed from the implementation in JS and CSS.
- This MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/-/merge_requests/20189 introduced a redesign that added the borderless class. This comment should be removed as it is out of date.

title: Vulnerabilities on the dependency page do not match vulnerability report page
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

While on the dependency page, the vulnerabilities associated underneath a dependency do not match the vulnerabilities on the vulnerability page. Specifically, the severity states do not match.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create java project with pom file
2. Include dependency com.fasterxml.jackson.core/jackson-databind:2.9.8
3. Run dependency scan

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
- Dependency List shows less vulnerabilities than Vulnerability Report

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Dependency List and Vulnerability Report show same vulnerabilities

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![image](/uploads/58679587a6f434fe5915f2ae9148f656/image.png)
![image](/uploads/095a6915e7e0cc27ebaf847fbc5e91c2/image.png)


### Possible fixes

(debated in [Root cause of the bug](#note_600679588))

this bug happens because of the way how vulnerabilities are picked up into Dependency List response. A special key is used to identify if this is new or already reported vulnerability https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/7ccd7a019efe8b61fa3e9962a17197ed423d0006/ee/lib/gitlab/ci/reports/dependency_list/dependency.rb#L31

this key is based on name of vulnerability rather than its identifier. So in case of vulnerabilities with the same name but different CVEs, only first vulnerability will be picked into report.

#### Implementation plan

1. add `id` field to `ee/spec/fixtures/security_reports/dependency_list/gl-dependency-scanning-report.json` as this fixture will be used to test this feature (and the fixture is outdated)
2. Add `id` to schema that `Formatters::DependencyList` produces.
3. Add `id` as a part of `DependencyList::Dependency#composite_key`
4. Add regression test for `#add_dependency` to check that vulnerabilities with the same name process correctly

title: Add data-testid for variable list feature spec
description:
### Problem

We are using the CSS class `.ci-variable-table` as a test selector in three feature specs.

- `spec/support/shared_examples/features/variable_list_shared_examples.rb`
- `spec/features/project_variables_spec.rb`
- `spec/features/project_group_variables_spec.rb`

If this class is ever removed the feature specs will fail unexpectedly since its a class meant for styling. 

### Solution

Lets add a `data-testid` to the locations `.ci-variable-table` is used. And use a selector meant specifically for testing. This will be explicit and ensure we don't mix styling with testing.

title: Improve performance of Repository Tags API under load into S3 tier
description:
**NOTE:** currently blocked by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitaly/-/issues/3592

After adding in a new performance test for the Repository Tags API it was found that endpoint is unperformant:

```
█ Results summary

* Environment:                10k
* Environment Version:        13.8.0-pre `41feec7b142`
* Option:                     60s_200rps
* Date:                       2021-01-22
* Run Time:                   1m 5.35s (Start: 10:50:23 UTC, End: 10:51:28 UTC)
* GPT Version:                v2.5.0

NAME                            | RPS   | RPS RESULT          | TTFB AVG | TTFB P90            | REQ STATUS     | RESULT
--------------------------------|-------|---------------------|----------|---------------------|----------------|----------------
api_v4_projects_repository_tags | 200/s | 182.98/s (>80.00/s) | 913.92ms | 1466.76ms (<2500ms) | 100.00% (>99%) | Passed
```

Looking at the environment metrics it appears that the bottleneck is Gitaly, which is getting hard by this endpoint:

![Screenshot_2021-01-22_at_10.52.36](/uploads/7010405a1f0605f0acf5463a2e91fce3/Screenshot_2021-01-22_at_10.52.36.png)

Testing was done as part of our normal performance tests on the 10k Reference Architecture at 200 RPS. In our test data (based on the main GitLab project) there are [numerous tags](https://staging.gitlab.com/gpt/large_projects/gitlabhq1/-/tags).

As per our [performance targets](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/issue-triage/#severity) the endpoint is above our main target of 500ms and falls under the ~"severity::2" tier. Task is to improve the endpoint's performance into the next tier ~"severity::3" (<2000ms).

title: Add pipeline_step db column to bulk_import_failures to track a step on which failure happened
description:
## Problem to solve

Currently when something goes wrong during Group Migration and bulk import failure is captured, it looks like this: 

![image](/uploads/6c7c5b20741b66848211a7afca4eb124/image.png)

While it's valuable to see which pipeline the error happened in, pipelines have multiple steps (extraction/transformation/loading) and current failure information does not provide which step pipeline failed on exactly. 

## Proposed solution

It would be useful to further extend `bulk_import_failures` and add `pipeline_step` db column to capture where exactly failure happened.

title: Each pipeline step should process individual records instead of a collection
description:
## Problem to solve 

Currently Bulk Import pipelines can either pass the whole collection through the pipeline at once or record by record, depending on pipeline (e.g. SubGroupEntitiesPipeline vs EpicsPipeline). Pipelines that use GraphQL Extractor pass the whole collection through the pipeline, which was working great until we started to need record-by-record processing. 

For example, in order to implement https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297459 we need to pass individual records thought the pipeline, since during transformation phase we check if parent epic exists in database in order to link epic with it's parent. This can't be done when passing the whole collection at once (since no parent is persisted yet). 

## Proposed solution 

1. Create a new standardised `ExtractedData` response class to wrap response from GraphQL/REST APIs in order to have unified interface 
2. Update `BulkImports::Common::Extractors::GraphqlExtractor` to use newly created response class to return `ExtractedData` object instead of raw hash
3. Update `BulkImports::Common::Extractors::GraphqlExtractor` and add new `key_path` option to replace `HashKeyDigger`. 
4. Remove `HashKeyDigger` transformer entirely, since there would be no need in it anymore. 
5. Make sure `BulkImports::Pipeline::Runner` yields individual records instead of the whole collection to transformers, so that by the time second record is being processed, first one is persisted.

title: Expose epic events in GraphQL API
description:
## Problem to solve

When using Group Migration and importing epics, imported data should include events as per https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/297465. This is currently not possible, since events are not exposed neither in GraphQL API nor REST API.

In order for migrated epics to be more 'complete' we need to expose events in GraphQL API (or REST API if GraphQL is not an option).

title: Naming and key path convention for Usage ping metrics
description:
## Problem




Currently we have under the [Naming and placing the metrics](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/usage_ping.html#1-naming-and-placing-the-metrics)

```
Add the metric in one of the top level keys

license: for license related metrics.
settings: for settings related metrics.
counts_weekly: for counters that have data for the most recent 7 days.
counts_monthly: for counters that have data for the most recent 28 days.
counts: for counters that have data for all time.
```

Opening this issue to discuss about the convention for the key path  of a metric in JSON payload

There are a couple of exceptions when we currently add new metrics. For example Redis counters go under same redis_hll_couters top level key

The current usage ping structure and naming convention is vague:
- there is a loosely defined structure of how to organize/nest counters, making it difficult to know where to put new counters.
- the naming convention is not standardized across all counters, making it difficult to know what to name new counters.


## Nesting structure
The goal is to keep this as flat as possible and instead to add details into the naming convention or event dictionary.

- license
- settings
- counts_7d
- counts_28d
- counts_all

## Naming convention of metrics and events:
- top_level: count_7d, count_28d, count_all, license, setting
- segmentation: group, project, user, none
- event_name: primary name in [event dictionary](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VzE8R72Px_Y_LlE3Z05LxUlG_dumWe3vl-HeUo70TPw/edit#gid=618391485)

For example: 
- `#{top_level}.#{segmentation}_#{event_name}` 
- count_all.projects_prometheus_active

## Event Dictionary:

We continue to add to the existing event dictionary: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1VzE8R72Px_Y_LlE3Z05LxUlG_dumWe3vl-HeUo70TPw/edit#gid=618391485

- product_owner: [section](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/blob/master/data/sections.yml), [stage](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/blob/master/data/stages.yml), [group](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/blob/master/data/stages.yml)
- product_category: [categories.yml](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/blob/master/data/categories.yml)
- implementation: snowplow js, snowplow ruby, redis hll, ordinary batch counter, etc.
- metric and event name
- description
- etc.

For example:
 
| metric and event name | product owner | product category | implementation | ... |
| ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ | ------ |
| count_all.projects_prometheus_active | ops.monitor | integrations | usage ping batch counting | ... |

## Migration Plan

- Create a v2 Usage Ping file and job that runs in parallel to the existing Usage Ping. Try to combine both CE and EE files together.
- Create a v2 Versions endpoint to collect Usage Ping. Write the raw usage data to a separate table.
- Run both v1 and v2 in parallel for two milestones.
- In the data warehouse, use dbt to transform the v1 structure to v2. This will ensure all previous data ends up in v2.
- Update all Sisense charts to read from v2 tables.

## Next steps
- [ ] Discuss proposal and ensure all use cases are covered
- [ ] Create data migration plan
- [ ] Update to new convention
- [ ] Proposal for top level keys https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/251011
- [ ] Add `metrics.yml` file under `lib/gitlab/usage_data` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/270107

title: Replace jq in compare_reports script in ci-templates project to pure ruby
description:
### Problem to solve 

We're currently using [jq](https://stedolan.github.io/jq/) in the [compare_reports.sh](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/1afd341324d4bdaa51d4091b00c64d98508f4739/scripts/compare_reports.sh#L36-45) script for filtering/sorting/sanitizing JSON before comparing the actual generated report to the expected report in the QA stage. Our usage of `jq` has become very complex, to the point where we need to start [writing tests](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215596) to ensure it functions as expected. 

In order to improve the maintainability and flexibility of the [`compare_reports.sh`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/master/scripts/compare_reports.sh) shell script, we will eventually be [migrating it to a ruby implementation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/299038).

Once this migration to ruby has been completed, the next step is to replace our usage of `jq` with a pure ruby implementation, which is the purpose of this issue.

### Further details

[compare_reports.sh](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/9aee1de0a744e49577d026f66f8164ba07fdef5d/scripts/compare_reports.sh) currently goes through the following steps:
1. `sanitize_and_diff_reports`
   1. filter the actual and expected reports **using `jq` filters**; the exact filter depends on the report type 
   1. compare the actual report to the expected report using `diff -u -b`
   1. report an error and exit 1 if there's a diff
1. `validate_report_json`
   1. get the commit ref of `security-report-schemas` based on the version stored in the actual report
   1. get the filename of the schema based on the type of the actual report
   1. fetch the JSON schema
   1. do JSON schema validation using Python
   1. report an error and exit 65 if validation fails

jq filters are used in the first step, when preparing the reports before comparing them.

### Intended users

* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)

### User experience goal

The [compare_reports.sh](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/49fc4c8b7103cfb1fdebf0b0c1f7de73186ff041/scripts/compare_reports.sh) script will be easier to maintain and follow by other developers, and we can add more test coverage using standard `ruby` tools such as [`rspec`](https://rspec.info)

### Implementation plan

with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/299038 we'll get a ruby script that do the same job as [compare_reports.sh](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/1afd341324d4bdaa51d4091b00c64d98508f4739/scripts/compare_reports.sh#L36-45)) 
1. Replace all the [jq](https://stedolan.github.io/jq/) filtering logic in the new compare_reports ruby script to ruby
1. Write unit tests if found missing test cases

### Further details

See [this discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/299038#note_487463453) for more details

### Availability & Testing

Unit tests will be added for the filtering/sorting/sanitizing component of `compare_reports.rb` ruby script

### Available Tier

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

`jq` from the [compare_reports.sh](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/blob/49fc4c8b7103cfb1fdebf0b0c1f7de73186ff041/scripts/compare_reports.sh) script is replaced by a `ruby` implementation with unit tests.

### What is the type of buyer?

~"GitLab Ultimate" ~"Enterprise Edition"

### Is this a cross-stage feature?

Yes, this affects all secure projects

### Links / references

- [Migrate compare_reports shell script in ci-templates to ruby](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/299038)
- [Add tests for compare_reports script in ci-templates project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/215596)

title: Allow groups to be re-imported
description:
## Problem to solve 

Once a group has been imported once, a subsequent (re)load of the group list will show the group as available for import again. This is good, but the user can't tell that a group has already been imported and may, by mistake, perform another import.

![import_my_group](/uploads/87160064fb2c15171608fa6cbcc55558/import_my_group.mov)

## Proposed solution

Create a first-class experience for re-importing, instead of the current experience where it somehow just works (sometimes). It should be obvious to the user when a group has already been imported at least once. For example, the button might say `Re-import`, instead of `Import`, or there could be a link there to the previous import(s).

In order to prevent re-importing attempts into an existing group, the default (proposed) group names should be suffixed with a `-1`. For example, re-importing a group named `my-group` would propose `my-group-1` as the target group name. Few notes on the suffix:
* It is acceptable to keep adding `-1`, instead of following the sequence to avoid following long sequences. This means that `my-group-1-1` would be proposed if `my-group-1` exists.
* If it is feasible, we could also add a random, humanly-readable suffix, typically used for deconflicting, such as `-color-animal`, i.e. `-blue-horse`, `teal-fish`... - UX would have to chime in on this, as it may need to become a pattern for deconflicting names in other places.
* This generation of the default group name should run only once, when the page is loaded (preferably async - after the page loads). If the user changes the target (parent) group in the dropdown, the proposed group name should not be automatically re-generated. The validation will highlight the conflict and the user will be able to (will be forced to) deconflict the name before importing. 

## MVC
Interaction notes on image (%"13.11")

![13.11_Re-import__1_](/uploads/b83970c67c16394a42d3a874162753da/13.11_Re-import__1_.jpg)

## Additional considerations

* It is acceptable that a "regular" user who has permissions to import a group can see the fact that another user performed an import on that same group.
* Partially successful imports (a situation where a new group was created, but something failed during the import) should also be treated as re-import. 
* However, a failed import after which there is no new group visible (not created, or created and then deleted) should be treated as a first-time import (not re-import).
* We need to be clear that re-import **does not** mean "sync" or "refresh" of the new group with the data from the old group. It is simply another one-time, one-way migration of a group that had already been migrated. 
* Importing or re-importing into an existing group is still not possible. Validation will be added in another issue to prevent this. - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/300427

## Figma design file

### [:art: Allow groups to be re-imported](https://www.figma.com/file/gziIKXOEP8wUhjBZGXzsXB/299498-Allow-groups-to-be-re-imported?node-id=1%3A27)

title: Investigate automatically installing Jira Connect App from GitLab
description:
### Topic to Evaluate

There are two parts to the GitLab/Jira integration. On the Jira side there is the "Jira Connect App" and on GitLab there is the "Jira Integration". We see a disparity between installation numbers where the Jira Connect app has thousands or tens-of-thousands of installs while the GitLab Jira integration has millions of projects using it. We would like to investigate if we could automatically install the Jira Connect App when a user sets up the GitLab integration.

There is a plugin API on the Jira side that we could potentially use: https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/UPM/pages/6094960/UPM+REST+API

### Tasks to  Evaluate

<!-- Outline the tasks with issues that you need to evaluate as a part of the implementation issue -->

- [x] Determine feasibility of the feature
- [x] Create issue for implementation or update existing implementation issue description with implementation proposal https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/323880
- [ ] Set weight on implementation issue
- [ ] If weight is greater than 5, break issue into smaller issues

### Risks and Implementation Considerations 

<!-- Identify any risks found in the research, whether this is performance, impacts to other functionality or other bugs -->

title: 🎨 Design: Inline site and scanner profile creation
description:
#### Problem

There is a lot of set-up required for on-demand scans. To create a scan from scratch, a user has to visit three separate screens to actually get the scan running (`create a scanner profile`, `create a site profile`, and `new on-demand scan`). 


#### Proposal

Drawing from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/267346#note_490235828, we should explore allowing users to create site and scanner profiles inline while on the `New DAST scan` page.

📽 [Video walkthrough](https://www.loom.com/share/8fcc1cde7fec4d988cbb1307ee13bd6b)

🎨 [Figma](https://www.figma.com/file/7CaJqOTOpPEOzkYkoU5bs5/DAST-Ondemand-Profile?node-id=5413%3A41815)

![select-create-new-profile](/uploads/07358033734fc6c4c9f457a8736ad3a2/select-create-new-profile.png)

##### Notes
 
- If user clicks `Cancel` when creating a profile, existing confirmation dialog should appear:

![Screen_Shot_2021-02-23_at_8.37.35_AM](/uploads/60998bd0aee3591754b929a9f04e3151/Screen_Shot_2021-02-23_at_8.37.35_AM.png)

- User should always be able to select a new profile from the dropdown, even if they have already started to create a new profile

title: [Feature flag] Enable API fuzzing configuration UI
description:
## What

Remove the `:api_fuzzing_configuration_ui ` feature flag ...

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::fuzz testing" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#g_secure-fuzz-testing`
- Best individual to reach out to: @avielle @pgascouvaillancourt 

## Beta groups/projects

If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example.

- TBD

## Roll Out Steps

- [ ] Confirm that QA tests pass with the feature flag enabled (if you're unsure how, contact the relevant [stable counterpart in the Quality department](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/#individual-contributors))
- [ ] Enable on staging (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true --staging`)
- [ ] Test on staging
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated
- [ ] Enable on GitLab.com for individual groups/projects listed above and verify behaviour  (`/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab feature_name true`)
- [ ] Coordinate a time to enable the flag with the SRE oncall and release managers
  - In `#production` mention `@sre-oncall` and `@release-managers`. Once an SRE on call and Release Manager on call confirm, you can proceed with the rollout
- [ ] Announce on the issue an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com
- [ ] Enable on GitLab.com by running chatops command in `#production` (`/chatops run feature set feature_name true`)
- [ ] Cross post chatops Slack command to `#support_gitlab-com` ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#where-to-run-commands)) and in your team channel
- [x] Announce on the issue that the flag has been enabled
- [x] Remove feature flag and add changelog entry https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325410
- [x] After the flag removal is deployed, [clean up the feature flag](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) by running chatops command in `#production` channel

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set --project=gitlab-org/gitlab feature_name false
```

title: New Danger check that ensures that a feature flag group is the same as the MR group label

title: Make Danger warn when a feature flag is removed and title doesn't include `[RUN ALL RSPEC] [RUN AS-IF-FOSS]`
description:
As suggested in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/issues/10343#note_485698591, we should make Danger warn when a feature flag is removed and title doesn't include `[RUN ALL RSPEC] [RUN AS-IF-FOSS]`.

Danger could even update the title directly (and even start a new MR pipeline).

title: Iterations report page assignee images too small
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Proposal 
On the iterations page within the Issues table at the bottom, the assignees images are quite small. This makes it difficult to determine who I'm looking at. They are set to 16px x 16px which appears to be the size within the Pajamas assets, but while I believe this may be a standard size for icons, I don't think it should apply to avatars. My proposal is that we up the size to 24px x 24px.
